con.para: Electricity is a type of energy that powers many things around us. From lights to computers, electricity makes life easier! But what is electricity? Let's learn about it!
Electric current is like a flow of water in a river, but instead of water, it's tiny particles called electrons that move through wires. It helps power devices when they are plugged in.
Voltage is like the "push" that makes the electric current flow. Resistance slows down the current, like a narrow river that makes water flow slower. Different materials resist the flow differently.

There are two types of circuits: series and parallel. In a series circuit, electricity flows in one path. In a parallel circuit, electricity flows through more than one path, so if one light goes out, the others stay on!
Magnetism is an invisible force that pulls certain metals toward magnets. Magnets have two polesâ€”north and south. Opposite poles attract, and similar poles repel each other.
Magnetic fields are areas around a magnet where magnetic forces can be felt. The earth itself is like a giant magnet with a magnetic field!
A permanent magnet always has magnetic power, like the ones on your fridge. An electromagnet is only magnetic when electric current flows through it.
Electricity and magnetism are linked! Moving electric current creates a magnetic field. This is called electromagnetism, and it's how devices like motors work.
Electromagnetic induction is the process of generating electric current using magnets. This is how generators in power plants produce electricity for our homes.

con.title: Everyday Uses of Electricity and Magnetism

con.para: We use electricity and magnetism in so many ways every day! From refrigerators to electric cars, both electricity and magnets help make things work.
